instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
No water damage. Just stopped working. visual inspection with no result, board seems ok. 


Power rails:

PPBUS - 0V ( not shorted)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 5.2V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>  - 0V  (not shorted)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>  - 0V (not shorted)
<SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0V


<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> no LDO have voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
So you don't get voltage on any <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> LDO?
Compare diode mode readings on all LDO with another board.
Any voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
i dont have another working board like this here. 


On <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> i get 5.2 V both sides.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
Any board with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> should have similar readings!

Post few basic voltages on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; <SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>/P, <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
got same board today (working)

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>  0.505 (0.505--> will put here working board)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL>  0.525 (0.521)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>  0.486 (0.482)


<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> are same almost may be with 0.001-0.003 difference that i think doesnt matter.



<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> - 1.2V

<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>/P  5V (both)

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>  1.2V 

<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>  2.2V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>  1.2V"
Post diode mode to ground.
Check <RESISTOR>R6906</RESISTOR> and <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>   - 0.150

<RESISTOR>R6906</RESISTOR>/05 are ok. About <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> is very strange because replaced it from donor board and not usb pulsing ( i have usb-c adapter that show V and Amps and it is blinking every 4-5 seconds ) and not recieving voltage, put back original and get 5V again. <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>   - 0.150"
That's no good.
Suspetcs are <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>/91, <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7078</CAPACITOR>, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; remove them (one by one), in this order.

Why don't you check diode integrity, instead of changing???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power. Stuck at 5V
threads.message:
I would like to use it but I dont know very well how diode integrity is working. 


What make you think that 0.150 is failing <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>/91, etc?
